thread.title: Curtis Glencross released by Avs, Mikko Rantanen still on roster
thread.title_full: Curtis Glencross released by Avs, Mikko Rantanen still on roster - The Denver Post

author: Terry Frei
title: Curtis Glencross released by Avs, Mikko Rantanen still on roster
text:
Rookie winger Mikko Rantanen still was with the Avalanche and practiced with the team Monday.
Veteran winger Curtis Glencross wasn't and didn't.
Three days before Thursday's regular-season opener against the Minnesota Wild, the Avalanche confirmed the release of Glencross from his professional tryout, reducing the roster to 25, counting Jack Skille, who isn't on the official roster because he's on a professional tryout.
That also included center Jesse Winchester, who will go on the injured list with concussion symptoms, so it's expected that Colorado will make only one more cut to get down to the regular-season roster limit of 23.
Coach Patrick Roy stopped just short of saying that Rantanen, Colorado's 18-year-old first-round draft choice, definitely was sticking with the Avalanche for the start of the season.
"We'll make a final decision tomorrow," Roy said. "But right now, I'll admit that it looks good."
Glencross, 32, played three exhibition games for the Avalanche on the professional tryout deal and didn't have a point.
"We didn't see enough in him," said Roy, saying he was competing for a spot with Borna Rendulic and "possibly" Dennis Everberg.
Roy said of Skille: "There again, we're going to have to decide tomorrow what we're going to do."
Rantanen said he hadn't yet been told he was sticking with the Avalanche.
Advertisement "I have not talked with anybody," Rantanen said. "Glencross, I didn't see him so I don't know, but nobody has said anything to me. I think we will be smart with that. . . Of course I want to stay. My goal is to work hard for the team and be with the team when the season starts, and now it's close. So let's see after this day."
Rantanen is one of six Avalanche players living in a hotel, along with Skille, Reto Berra, Rendulic, Everberg and Brandon Gormley. The young Finn had one goal and no assists in five exhibition games for the Avalanche.
"That last game against L.A., they had a solid lineup, the best lineup you could have, so when you see you can battle with those guys and with the best D-men in the world, of course it gives you confidence," he said. "But you have to play well to play in this league."
Rantanen has signed a three-year entry level contract that will kick in if he plays in 10 regular-season NHL games. So it's possible, even probable, that he essentially will be playing the start of the season under what amounts to a trial and then the Avalanche will make a decision on what would be best for his development â€” staying with Colorado, going down to San Antonio of the American Hockey League or returning to play another season in the Finnish professional league with TPS Turku.
"I'm a young guy and I have never played in the NHL yet," Rantanen said. "The first nine games, the biggest thing is to get the team to win and I want to help with that and play well."
